description:
Ayola. It's the most convenient thing to my SF office. It's also not bad. Not bad, at all! When it comes down to it, gyros places often seem like a dime a dozen. And in many cases, they are. But Ayola delivers something above the average gyros joint. 

My normal go-to here is the greek salad with gyros meat (sometimes shawarma chicken) on top. The lettuce is fresh, the dressing is tasty, and the meat portion is generous. It's an easy keto meal for my lunchtime needs. I just skip the bread that comes with it, and I add in some of their house hot sauce, which is delicious (and if it's not made in house, someone tell me where I can buy it!). 

Service is crazy quick during the lunchtime rush. Staff is friendly and motivated. Portions are fairly generous for the price. And the convenience? Can't be beat.
author: Don B.

description:
Sigh. The prices have gone up and the portions and quality have gone down. I ordered a falafel pita wrap and was surprised at how much smaller it was than before. The falafel was a bit dry, and they definitely skimped on the tahini sauce (although you can pay extra if you would like more).

What disappointed me the most was half way through my meal, a piece of meat fell out of my falafel pita wrap. As a vegetarian, this really annoyed me, and I was forced to dispose of the rest of my meal (which double pains me because I do not like to waste food).

I'm not sure if I came to Ayola on a bad day, but I'm not sure I'll be venturing back any time soon.
author: Sejal D.

description:
Decent Greek lunch items. Reasonable price. 

Really annoying that online orders don't get started or made or ready before you walk in the door. 

Hello?????  It's easier to just walk in and order. Plus, that doesn't make me feel like they mistrust me until I show up.
author: Lanny B.

description:
Great and very convenient lunch spot! I'm a fan of Greek food so I thought why not check them out. Friendly cashier and a clear, big menu up above. Pretty inexpensive and a short wait. It's a very small shop so try to get there just before the lunch rush or prepare to get up close and personal with other hungry customers. 

I got the falafel sandwich and a side of fries. Good portion size, enough for leftovers. Not bad! They have some type of sauce on the counter for you to take. I recommend grabbing some because my stuff wasn't that flavorful. I'd go back and maybe try the gyros, (singular, pronounced YEE-ros, and yes they have a button at the counter to educate you).
author: Liz B.

description:
Often forgotten little spot tucked away on New Montgomery.

Ever since they introduced their rice bowls, I've been grabbing one at least once a week or more!

Curried rice, Lamb & Beef, Tzatziki Sauce, & I tend to substitute the Peasant Salad with the Greek Salad. I'm not the biggest fan of tomatoes.

My other go to is the Lamb & Beef Gyro Platter. That hummus + Pita Bread, YUMMM!! 

The staff is always super friendly and accommodating. The food comes out super quick. 

It has become one of my regular lunch time spots. Give it a try if you have not yet!
author: My N.

description:
Ok this place is no longer good. I tried the chicken shawarma rice and it was terrible. The rice was not good not fresh. The chicken was just dry and hard. Hardly the shawarma I've had at other places. The hot sauce used to be tasty but he new one is bad. 
I used to like this place and I have previous reviews but now this place is pretty bad. Won't go back.
author: Arjan N.

description: Went for a quick bite and took lamb gyro which was really good. Also dont forget to take the sauce that is on the counter which by the way is really good. Also liked the quick service here.
author: Sharad B.

description: Great fast lunch spot in downtown SF. They have fast lunch boxes to go that are delicious and easy to grab. There will be a short line at lunch time, but it moves quickly. Highly recommend trying one of their lunch rice bowls!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Mediterranean is probably my all-time favorite food genre, and as long as it's fresh and hearty, I'm not too picky. Ayola is not the most amazing, nor the most cost effective Med in town. Bu it IS convenient, quick, and always filling.  They keep the line moving crazy fast, and the staff are smiley and accommodating. I find their hummus a bit bland, but the baba ganoush is smokey good. Spicy red sauce with everything. 

For my vegan amigos, there are many options for you too. The combo platter is my go-to and can be veganized by swapping the tzaziki for tahini. Ta-da!
author: Nique F.

description: Tiny tiny little spot but they serve a mean gyro!
author: Sunil R.

description:
I always get the falafel pita sandwich and it's fantastic!

It's a super efficient takeout place with solid Mediterranean food. They're quick and the guy at the counter is super nice. It's my go to place when I have to grab a quick lunch and go back.

My only minor pain is that the sandwiches are sometimes messy to eat (because it's a pita wrap basically that can make some of the stuffing to come out) but I can live with that. Totally recommend it!!
author: Vignesh B.

description:
Overall a little bit too garlic-y for my taste. Most of the combos are very affordable and pretty good for the price, so I'd definitely recommend Ayola if you're in a rush during lunch break and need to find something inexpensive and fast.

If you're looking for quality though, there're definitely many better places in SoMa.
author: Antonio H.

description:
Ayola is a nice spot to stop at for lunch during the week. They are always pretty quick and the lamb "gyro" meat is pretty good. I have had their Greek salad, traditional gyro, and their newest addition to the menu the  gyro bowl. 

I haven't been disappointed when I get a lunch from there. It is super quick and affordable.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
This is a solid Greek/Mediterranean street food fair. The location is so convenient for grabbing a lunch on the go there that sometimes it is a no-brainer.
Order a gyros sandwich, 7- or 9-inch, if you are hungry. Or a salad if you want something healthy. And don't forget the hot sauce that they give out for free in the small containers on the counter.
They have lately started experimenting with the rice bowls, following a trend established by some other places nearby. They are okay, but they don't quite compare with the classic gyros sandwich with their fries. Oh yeah, did I mention: don't forget the fries?!
author: Jakub S.

description:
We got lunch catered at the office from Ayola (not sure which location) and the food was bomb diggity. The gyro meat was really well seasoned, it would have been delicious on it's own. But why eat it alone when there's tasty tzatziki, bombass babaganoush, and holy-mother-of-deliciousness hot sauce to go with it. Seriously, that hot sauce is out of this world.

Put on your Nikes and get yourself here. Just do it.
author: Chanel H.

description: Great Mediterranean option for lunch near work. Usually really quick- especially if you order for pick up on Yelp. Their gyro platter is really good.
author: Jenny J.

description:
Good lunch/early takeout dinner option. The lamb/beef rice bowl is what keeps me coming back. Gyro meat, rice, cucumber/tomato salad.

Prices are reasonable and service is fast.
author: J.P. M.

description:
I loved coming here for lunch as an intern in SF! The service is super quick and it's super convenient for lunch on the go.

The restaurant is fairly easy to locate but fair warning: it's tiny! Don't anticipate dining in. There are two stools and a tiny counter table probably mostly used for waiting. Probably why they always wrap things to go is because there's no seating really. I really wished they did have some seating options!

I've always gotten their chicken gyros and I stopped by again today and it's still yummy and how I remembered it 2 years ago now so they're doing great on consistency. They cook and spice their chicken so well. The meat is not dry at all, it's super tender. The tzatziki sauce works perfectly with the chicken and the whole experience was not just one note. The pita added a good warmth that balanced the coolness of the tzatziki and the chicken just works well to give the gyro body. 

I've also tried their lam gyro, fries and falafel+dolmas and their all pretty well made standard Mediterranean fare but the chicken gyro totally blows my mind so would highly recommend!

Make sure you get the red sauce from the counter!! Not sure what it is exactly but it gives the gyro the perfect kick.
author: Annie P.

description:
This restaurant is right next to my office and a co-worker recommended it so I decide to try it. I ordered the Shawarma rice plate which was average. The rice was decent and they give salad on the side. The chicken was rubbery :( 

The place gets crowded during lunch time but service was still fast.
However, I am going to give them another try incase I went on an off day.
author: Lovejit K.

description:
Great food, priced right, friendly workers and clean establishment. In a world of Chipotles and Starbucks, be an Ayola customer. They do not disappoint and it won't hurt your wallet. I recommend the Greek salad with gyro meat or the lamb gyro. Both amazing.

My one issue is they aren't open on weekends despite Yelp stating they are until 3pm. I saw a few people try to get food there just to realize they were closed.
author: Jessica D.

description: Fast, delicious, and clean Greek food in the middle of SOMA! I've walked past Ayola for almost the year and a half that I was working in the area but recently switched jobs and this has become one of my go-to places, now. The all veg and chicken troy salads are both great (and the portion size is enough to save some food for dinner). They'll also kindly pack the dressing on the side if you ask.
author: Meryam B.

description:
I love San Francisco, but sometimes I feel like I'm eating unhealthy all week because all the food there is just SO good. I was in the Financial District for work when my friend/colleague Yelp Indy said, "Man, I just want some vegetables." Preach, girl, preach.

Enter Ayola, which was close to our office and inexpensive. It's a super small establishment, but I have to give the staff credit because it was a well-oiled machine. It's also strictly takeout only. These guys and gals are ready for the SF lunch hour rush with no fear, even when the line starts to bunch in the awkward cluster and everyone doesn't know where the line starts and ends. I ordered a salad and a piece of baklava. Ok, I know I was just complaining about eating like trash while traveling, but I'm also not insane. If an authentic Greek place has baklava on the menu, of course, I have to order it. Research. You know?

Whoa, baby, my salad was so large, I couldn't even finish it. In most cases, a salad is just a salad, so nothing super memorable about it, and I got the veggies I was hoping for. The baklava hit the spot, too, and I didn't even feel bad after. Ayola is a completely solid option if you need a quick, reasonably priced lunch or dinner. They have great hours as well (10am-7pm), so there's no reason to not stop by.
author: Lauren K.

description:
I wanted to grab a quick dinner and decided to check out this place. It was pretty empty in there around 6PM. I got the Gyro combo plate, it came out within 20 seconds! Wow!

Inside had hummus, lamb gyro, salads, pita beard and two sauces (balsamic vinegar and yogurt). Sauces were decent and pita beard was pretty good. Gyro was very dry, wasn't feeling it. The salad had some tomatoes that were not fresh and was kind of turning brown. EW.

Overall, not sure if I would come here again, but I think its a good place for a quick bite.
author: Natalie L.

description: The chicken shawarma platter was tasty! However, I am knocking down the review since they forgot to give pita bread and missed another item on my order.
author: Renee G.

description:
Ayola is my go-to place for a quick lunch while at work. It's located in the heart of the financial district and is set up to cater to the grab n go lunch crowd. I usually get a Falafel wrap here, but the Gyro platter and the combo platters are delicious as well.

The quantity of food here is reasonable, it's not so heavy that you can't work in the afternoon, but also not so bad that you need to grab a second lunch. The French fries are fantastic and their hot sauce is great too. The service is quick and the price is reasonable. Not much more to say. I'd recommend Ayola to anyone who wants to grab a quick lunch and likes Mediterranean food.
author: Aditya V.

description: Went here because I was craving something different for lunch. Decided to try their new Gyro lamb & beef rice bowl. I really enjoyed it! Meat was very well seasoned and tender. Location was super crowded during lunch time as expected but got my food in a decent amount of time, around 10 minutes. The food came out very hot so I assume it was made fresh! Will be going back
author: LeVar H.

description:
If you order the chicken gyro, I recommend you ask them to hold the tin foil. 

It wasn't even part of the frickin' packaging of my to-go order! It is nicely metallic-tasting otherwise.
author: M. E.

description:
I don't know how many times I've craved a gyro and passed by this place, it's such a shame! I'm big on Mediterranean food and find myself always itching for some lamb- I'm surprised I never felt inclined to visit this place as it is just a block away from my office. I tried the food today for the first time and I regret not ever coming here to satisfy my gyro craving! My first impression of this place was that it was a typical-looking Mediterranean place right next to work, with a typical menu. Nothing too fancy. The place is very casual. The cashier was super friendly and the service was quick. I didn't wait very long for my order. Perfect for a quick bite.

I ordered the gyro (lamb and beef), a chicken gyro (for my brother), and the fries, which they claim to be the best fries in town. So I paid around 22 bucks for two 7-inch gyros and an order of fries- not too bad. You could get an 9-inch gyro for a dollar more. The lamb and beef gyro was dee-lish! The meat was well-flavored but not overly salty, which when too salty, tends to take away from the meat's natural flavors. The lettuce was crunchy and fresh, unlike other places with sad and droopy lettuce (probably because they use romaine rather than the typical iceberg). I really enjoyed the tzatziki sauce they had. But I really enjoyed the hot sauce, which had a subtle tint of oregano....? Whatever it was, the flavor went really well with my gyro. 

I'm a fan of fries and I don't know about you, but I'm all about firm, crispy fries. You know, the kind that hold their shape and don't end up soggy after ten minutes? You want crispy fries? Ayola's got them. The fries were nice and firm, they kept their form throughout my entire lunch period, and were really mealy on the inside. The fries weren't seasoned very much, so they weren't too salty, but I like my fries that way. 

I basically just found my new gyro joint. Will be coming back to try everything else on the menu!
author: Meghan J.

description:
Ayola is probably one of the most underrated joints in FiDi. It's a small takeaway joint sandwiched in between Chipotle and Working Girls Cafe and I wouldn't notice it unless I was really paying attention or looking for it. 

The chicken shawarma and gyro are really great since the tahini, meat and the lavash wrap go very well together. They also have a rice bowl combo which I'm not a big fan of. Then again, I'm not big on rice anyways. 

The lines are short, the service is quick and yes, you will see people come in and order just the fries. Ayola fries are a thing!
author: Gaurav K.

description:
Got our office lunch on Friday, September 30th from Ayola. It arrived via Forkable around 12 noon.

4-Item Make Your Own Combo Platter ($12): Served with pita and your choice of dishes
*Item 1: Tabouleh Salad
*Item 2: Falafel
*Item 3: Tzatziki
*Item 4: Hummus
*Add: Chicken Breast (+$3.35)

I love variety, so this was perfect for me. I enjoyed the hummus. It was creamy and flavorful. The tabouleh was also good. Gave everything I ate with it a nice texture and freshness. The chicken was okay. Not much flavor. I found it kind of bland. You definitely need to add hummus and hot sauce to it. The falafel was all right as well. Crispy on the outside, but I found this bland too. And it was a little too dense for me. I gave my coworker one and he seemed to like it though. The tzatziki was the most disappointing. It didn't have that tart flavor I love. It was more reminiscent of a creamy mayo, which I found it a little odd.

Overall, Ayola was okay. I'm glad I was able to try a variety of things, but I think there are better options for Mediterranean in the area.
author: Elena N.

description: Great lunch time options that are healthy and always taste fresh. The schwarma bowls will hit the spot and the salads will leave you full. Their falafel is also pretty great. Oh, can't forget their fries, those fries are nice and crispy and seasoned light. Ordering ahead will save you some time, but walking in and out with food is always a quick affair. Staff is super friendly and attentive.
author: Tate C.

description: I frequent this place for lunch for several reasons. The food is delicious, the service is fast, the price is reasonable, and they hook up the protein on their salads. You get more for your money than elsewhere locally in my opinion.
author: Coleman T.

description: Place gets packed during the lunch hour, so get there early or after 1 when the crowd has died down.  Got the gyros often, but recently the past few times I've gone the food has become too salty and sloppy.  Even when I get there when there's no crowd, they prepared my gyros so fast and so sloppy.  Get yourself a fork, just in case.  Food tastes good, but I could go somewhere else where they don't saturate the food with salt.
author: Chan L.

description: A hole in the wall Greek restaurant mainly to go. Lines out the door for a good reason. Great lunch place with amazing French fries. I have tried their rice and it was amazing they have great gyros and platters and fabulous salads with chicken or gyros meat. I strongly recommend it for lunch.
author: Rula T.

description:
Very very mediocre food, even for the fast lunch. No napkins or chips sauce. 

The downtown gets really busy during lunch time. Ayola has a line out of the door every day, so it should be good, right? That's what i thought.

My colleague and I had chicken Gyros and, claimed to be "best fries in town."

The place is fast paced and they are making orders fast. However, my Gyro was poorly constructed and fell apart mid way.

Too much sauce caused my chicken Gyro to drip a lot. And guess what? There were no napkins in the bag! My togo order was not ready for me to eat on the go. 

The chicken was not a shawarma chicken. It was a white boiled chicken, with a lot of Taziki sauce. That's it.

Fries were ok, but definitely not "best in town." More like "these are ok to eat." They were lightly salted a barely peppered. 

In short: it is fast and affordable but there are great food options around, Ayola is not the best.
author: Julia G.

description:
My compulsive job-hopping had finally bounced me back to this SOMA neighborhood, and I was delighted to find Ayola still here and flourishing. The tabouli, dolmas, spanakopita and chicken and rice soup are as satisfying as ever, and I'm ashamed to say it's only been in the last month that I've gotten around to trying their gyros... wonderful!

The staff are still adorable
author: Mutant O.

description: I used to really like this place but ownership changed recently which was reflected in a decline of the food's flavor. I was willing to give it a chance to improve and have been ordering lunch about once a week but today my baba ganoush was spoiled and inedible. I don't plan on going back.
author: Russ S.

description:
This place is pretty great! 

I tried chicken shawarma and lamb gyro and both were delicious! The fries are amazing, watch yourself because you will gulp down the whole bag before you know it. 

I would recommend the sandwiches over the combo platter as far as meat is concerned to me it doesn't taste as good solo! But that being said the salads and hummus are also delicious!!

Great food especially for the price. Check it out and make sure to grab a hot sauce on your way out!
author: Molli W.

description: Good place for lunch. They are doing really good Greek wraps (Gyros), although portions are small, and even big Gyro wrap (which costs above 10 bucks), won't leave me full. So I visit only if I need to eat something quickly - Gyro Wraps fit this gap perfectly. For proper full lunch, there are a bunch of other options nearby.
author: Dmytro Z.

description:
I've been lacking in the Mediterranean and Greek Department for my taste buds. So I decided to reconnect with that side. 

Also honestly I was getting hangry as well. I decided to stop by Ayola since it was closer and had more reviews than the other place across the street and I'm glad I did. 

I asked the cashier what's the most popular item which is their gyros but he said his personal favorite is the chicken shawarma so I decided to go with that. We also ordered falafels as well. 

The service was nice and the food came out fast. The food was really good although I would like a bit more seasoning with my food. The hot sauce they have is spicy and delicious. The falafels were super crunchy on the outside but soft on the inside and it wasn't like 50% batter or anything. It was like 99.99% batter so you could taste the filling inside. 

If you're ever by Kearny or China Town area check them out for the perfect lunch spot!
author: Yinja L.

description:
My husband dreams of their chicken shawarma, rice and baba ghanoush. 
I'm certain that they have the best falafel that I've tasted in San Francisco - tied with on other establishment for best falafel that I've tasted in U.S. 
The beef & lamb gyros are also delicious and the pita is fluffy, light, soft, delectable. 
Their food, at least, at lunch, tastes remarkably fresh.  All other falafel and gyro places in the FIDI are now dead to me.
author: Laura M.

description:
Seeked out Ayola for a Wednesday lunch with some old buddies and found the small joint packed with people. Once you walk in, the people behind the register are not afraid to command for the next person to spit out their order and pay immediately. The man asked me what I wanted and I glanced at the board and reported the first one I saw - the Combo Platter.

After I paid, I walked away and thought, damn! I want the Gyro platter! Oh well, next time! Either way, the reviews for Ayola are not a joke! They are very fast and very efficient. There are no names that are being called, just the number. So don't walk outside after you order and don't put the ticket in your pocket, once they call you, they expect you there. If you're not there, they will begin to question their slips and you see their tense faces become annoyed. 

Since there were no seating here, the buddies and I decided to visit a POPOS on 2nd and Market. Yes, this is a private owned public place for you to sit and enjoy lunch with your friends! The combo platter came with four sections. Salad with cheese and tomatoes, the fried vegetarian balls, and two sections of hummus. They were all delicious and the fried balls were 10xs better after sinking it into the hummus.

I wish that I could have easy access Ayola all the time! But at least they're quick, so I can get to and from my work place and still have time to slowly enjoy my food!
author: Linda K.

description: This place serves very good middle eastern food. I took the 7" falafel wrap, the veggie option and the flavor was really good. Sometimes you need to ask for the hit sauce and it is really a must thing to take
author: Prashanth B.

description: My default weekly spot for lunch. 2-3 times a week. The people there are very nice! Food are very fresh and tasty. No too salty but very flavored! I had similar places around my office as well but nothing compared to theirs!
author: Ying L.

description: My favorite gyro meat in SF. It is juicy, seasoned nicely, and generous portions. Their chicken is also AMAZING. tzatziki sauce off the chain. Overall awesome place. Wish they had a restaurant so we could do date nights here.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
My favorite is the Troy salad. Such good Gyro meat without the mess of a wrap! The salad itself isn't anything to write home about - lettuce, some feta cheese, onions, a couple tomatoes and a couple of olives. But like I said, the meat is so good you don't need fancy toppings. 

Also, they're fast during the lunch hour which is sometimes all you need on a work day.
author: Kelly G.

description: This is a good go to Greek place for lunch. It is quick and the quality is pretty good. They are technologically advanced with order stand and part of the latest app delivery programs. My Gyro was really good. I will be going back when the office wants Greek.
author: Ken A.

description: I work close to this place and it's really a good option to get satisfying food quickly. The pita- hummus, baba ganoush, rice  are all good/decent taste at a very good price by SF standards. Its not a sit down restaurant but more of a grab-and-go place. Exactly what you need for busy work days. The people taking orders have been warm most of the times.
author: Tejashree M.

description:
The only thing Ive ordered here are the fries, but they are a great afternoon snack when youre on a cheat day. 

Ive heard their special house sauce is to die for. Im not a huge fan of sauce, but worth try!
author: Claire W.

description:
Solid lunch spot on our office lunch list. I've gotten delivery from Ayola several times through DoorDash and usually bounce back and forth between either the chicken shawarma or a combo platter. 

Recommend: 
CHICKEN SHAWARMA is offered in either 7" or 9". I always get the 7" but I also spring for the fries + soda combo. The fries are crispy outside and soft on the inside. I usually can't finish the whole meal because of the fries so I would save half of the shawarma for a late afternoon snack. Yay! Be forewarned that it gets messy eating this since they don't skimp on the chicken so have a fork or fingers ready to pick up the aftermath of your chicken falling off your shawarma. 

COMBO PLATTER is a great way to get a bunch of sides as samplers. I think they have a set combo platter that has: hummus, dolmas, eggplant salad, falafel, and tzatziki sauce. AND it comes with pita bread. I also believe there is baba ganoush in the combo but it isn't listed on the menu. Really good deal if you're too indecisive to pick and choose items. It's also a great value since there's at least 5 items. After trying the combo once, on my second time, I decided to do a choose my own 4-item platter to try out the spanakopita, tabouleh salad, baklava, and falafel (again!). 

Reviewing the sides alone (from most favorite to least):
-Baklava: Delicious dessert that is flaky on top and sweet in the middle. 
-Spanakopita: Very flaky pastry with a savory spinach filling.
-Falafel: Excellent. Crispy outside and flavorful inside. I like to dip it in the tzatziki sauce.
-Baba ganoush: Slightly smoky flavor. Good to eat on its own.
-Dolmas: I like the inside filling but the outside had a tad too much lemon juice. 
-Eggplant salad: Alright. Only enjoyed the eggplant. 
-Hummus: Average. But to be fair, I was full from the rest of the combo platter.  
-Tabouleh salad: Tasted rather plain to me but if you love parsley, then it's your salad.
author: Diana C.

description:
If management reads this...Did you change the gyro meet?  Lamb & Beef

This is a great spot for your Greek & Mediterranian food needs!  I got a gyro today and the meat flavor has changed...that's the reason for the 4 stars.
author: Samuel R.

description: Tasty!  Only wish they had ketchup for their fries. But one of the better gyros I've had in the states.
author: Bill H.

description:
Ayola adds a little variety to the neighborhood with Mediterranean dishes - falafel, Greek salads, hummus, tzatziki, and so on. This little Greek spot is essentially the size of a takeout counter. There are only a few seats by the window, but there are public parklets nearby for you to enjoy your lunch. 

I usually order a gyro or a shawarma. I'm still not quite clear what is the difference between the two. Hopefully someone will clearly explain it to me one day, but everyone seems to have a slightly different explanation of each. 

Gyros & Shawarmas are about $8 for 7 inches, and $9 for 9 inches. It is a marginal difference, but the extra dollar is worth the extra 2 inches. I typically order the 7 inch. I once ordered the 9 inch, hoping to eat half and save the rest for later, but ended up devouring the entire sandwich.
The shaved gyro meat of lamb & beef are tasty and have good flavor. I couldn't tell the difference between lamb & beef, but I took that as a good sign, since I couldn't detect any gamey taste. 
The chicken gyro is quite good too. The chicken shawarma, as far as I can tell, is made with roasted chicken instead. The lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, & red onions taste very fresh and crisp. I usually request it without red onions, but sometimes they forget to take them out. Their tzatziki is creamy, yet refreshing. I've tried to make my own tzatziki and it was okay, but of course, not as good as theirs. The best part is the warm, soft, thick pita bread. 

Their fries are delicious as well. I'm not even a big fan of fries, but I can appreciate that they're served hot and seasoned well. They're more of a thick cut with a slightly mushy center. 
They even have containers of sauces right on the counter, so you can help yourself without having to pump your own sauce. 

The office ordered catering for a meeting once, so I decided to take the opportunity to try all the things I was curious to try. (Speaking of boring meetings, does it bother anyone else to see people show up to take their order & give a rushed, 'Sorry so busy, I can't stay.' Right, yet not too busy for free food.) 
Anyways, I opted for the 4-Item Combo Platter with pita for $10.75. 
I chose Dolmas, Tzatziki, Hummus & Baklava, and added Gyro Meat for $3. 
I slathered some tart hummus on the pita bread. Not bad. 
Then I dunked the pita into the tzatziki and sandwiched it with some gyro meat. Pretty good.
The dolmas were too tart for me. I've always been curious to try stuffed grape leaves. I wasn't quite sure what they were filled with, but I was expecting them to be more salty than sour. 
Surprisingly it was more food than I could finish, so I ate the leftovers for a snack later that day.

I was most looking forward to trying the baklava. The sweet layers of crunchy pastry & sweet, crushed walnut filling with some pistachio dust on top was so good. I actually took it home to share with Mr. Joy, who has a slight walnut allergy, but he didn't have a reaction to it. For an extra $2, this is a pretty good way to satisfy a sweet tooth. 

There is usually a line around lunchtime, but there are lines everywhere at noon. Their line actually appears long because they have limited space, so it's not unusual to see people lining out the door, but the service is actually pretty quick. I'll stick to the gyros, but it'll be pretty hard to resist the baklava going forward.
author: Joy W.

description:
Location: Nice walk from yerba buena, bart, etc. Inside is really small, so try to order online to just pick up! Pick up is on the left of the cash register, so just don't stand in line for a pick up

Food comes out really quickly! Baklava is sooo good (5/5). Shawarma wrap was great as well - careful of the red sauce!! It's pretty spicy.
author: Shelley K.

description:
As much as I hated my job, the only thing I look forward to is lunch time? Why? Ayola. Their chicken wraps are over the top hefty and filled with meaty goodness. That sauce though is a cherry on top for my cravings. I swear it's creamy, spicy, and just on point. 

Craving this now. I guess I'll Postmates it. 

BTW, it's huge (that's what she said).
author: Joyce L.

description:
Super fast, even when the line's out the door, and especially when ordering ahead on Eat24 (protip: no need to wait in line - go to the left side of the counter). It's tiny and crowded so definitely plan on taking it to-go.

The pita sandwiches (gyros) are good (def go for the small splurge to upgrade to the bigger size) but my go-to is the combo platter of hummus, baba ganoush, falafel, dolmas, salad, tzatziki, and pita. It's on the pricier side for lunch (note many of the menu pics on Yelp are dated), but it's quite filling and I love the variety. I just wish the hummus and baba ganoush weren't in a pool of olive oil - I try to eat around it.
author: Cristina S.

description:
My boss took me here for lunch and as many hole in the walls, it lives up to its small space. I got the beef and lamb gyro and it was perfect. I have always been a fan of Wally's in Emeryville, and this is a strong second place. 

The gyro had thinly tomato slices, chopped lettuce, yogurt sauce in the middle and a good amount of meat. The meat is juicy on the inside and crispy on the outside which made the gyro work perfectly with my side order of fried.

The food came quiet quickly, and tasted amazing.. 

I was extra happy that the fries were seasoned well, and was the perfect size for a lunch. I will try the plates or salad next time, maybe this week...
author: Mei L.

description: Hole-in-the-wall in the sense that this is a tiny carry out joint (literally nothing more than a hole in the wall) and, well, it's no frills. It certainly got the job done for today's fast and budget-friendly lunch outing. I opted for the chicken and rice soup, baklava and the cucumber and tomato salad. Unfortunately, after I made it back to my hotel I found that the salad didn't make it into my bag but the good news is, the chicken and rice soup made up for it. I believe they used the same meat from their chicken shawarma in the soup which really boosted the flavor along with the celery and carrots. This is certainly a go-to soup if you're feeling under the weather. The staff was super friendly and handled their lunchtime crowd with ease. I was impressed by how quickly we received the food and how the team balanced a smile on their face with the line rolling out the door. I'll certainly be back for the soup.
author: Brittany S.

description:
i just got a gyro from here. it was around 10$. look at the picture that's attached to this review and tell me how it looks. in one word, i would summarize it as: UNINSPIRED. 
in three words: uninspired and LAZY
in 5 words: uninspired, lazy, bland and SLOPPY.
i don't know how this place has 4 solid red stars. this is the most depressing meal i've in at least 11 months. 
of course i ate it. i'm not gona throw it away. but i didn't enjoy it. and quite frankly i feel like 200 pounds of bird shit right now and this has potentially ruined my weekend. #scust #sadtime
author: A C.

description:
I needed a quick meal before a meeting and this was the perfect place to grab one. Cheap, fast, easy, and good. I got a gyro and it was pretty filling. The gyro was really good and tender, the veggies were pretty fresh and the pita was good. I'm not a fan of tiziki sauce, so I had them put just a little bit. Even with just a little the gyro was full of flavor. They also have hot sauce too. That is really good, but grab a cup of water because it's on the spicy side. 

Overall, it was a delicious quick meal.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Ingredients are fresh and food is prepared quickly. Friendly workers will help you decide on their variety of choices. I've ordered the vegetarian combo platter and 7 inch falafel. The 7 inch sandwich is quite generous, as was the combo platter. Hummus and falafel are good. There are a few seats, so many people order food to go. It's busy, so I suggest ordering online. Ayola would be great for an office lunch or party.
author: Carol W.

description:
The gyros come lukewarm, even during peak weekday lunch hours. The only thing that was warmed for my order was the pita, all the other ingredients were room temperature or refrigerated. Cold wraps are so disappointing.

 My biggest problem is that the meat in my chicken gyro tasted a bit off, and I didn't want to finish my food out of fear of getting food poisoning.
author: Meg A.

description:
Ayola's chicken gyro twice in one week? Yup.
Just be warned, the handhelds are messy, so make sure you have lots of napkins when consuming!

The spot is strictly take-out, but there's a park nearby where you can enjoy your food when the weather permits, or just take it back to the office like I did. I highly suggest you order your food ahead of time as the line tends to wrap outside the small eatery right around. Eat24 lets you choose, pay and tip all in a quick transaction with your food being ready for pick-up a short time after. Super convenient.

Back to the gyro. It comes in two sizes, 7" or 9". The first time around I went for the smaller portion and regretted my decision quickly after. It's filled with lettuce, tzatziki sauce and a nice heap of tender chicken and surrounded by a giant piece of pita bread and served in a piece of foil. Because they don't skimp, once you take your initial bite, things begin to fall out if you're not careful. This is not a bad thing, but just have a fork nearby to pick up the remnants or you'll look like a caveman scooping up leftovers with your fingers. I did just that in front of my co-workers, but couldn't let anything go to waste.

If chicken isn't your things, they have a beef, lamb, vegetarian and eggplant versions available for the choosing as well. Someone said I had to order the fries, but I haven't had the opportunity to try them yet. I guess it calls for another trip to Ayola for lunch before I leave!
author: Ryan C.

description: I started going here with my MealPal subscription and am always glad when I do.  The quality and taste of the food is excellent!
author: Christopher M.

description:
Grabbed a quick lunch from Ayola during a business trip to downtown San Francisco. I was craving gyros, so I had to check the place out.

Small space, but it doesn't seem like anyone stayed to eat. Service was friendly and the turnaround was pretty fast. The gyros plate was very filling, especially with the hummus and bread. The gyro meat was juicy and a touch crispy, just how I like it with the tzatziki. The salad itself wasn't anything to write home about, but the majority of the plate was overall solid.

I'd come again to try the sandwich next time I'm in town. I'd definitely recommend it for a quick lunch!
author: Ehow C.

description:
I know I was just bad-mouthing brunch earlier this week so I won't press my luck with nay-saying lunch, but I will say that I typically prefer to eat my first meal of the day post-5pm. 

My eating schedule is a little unconventional, but I eat 95% of my meals alone so it usually works out really well for me. 

Then there's that remaining 5% of the time when I'm around other humans and it's lunch time and they suggest we get some lunch and I want to continue interacting with them and though I'm not really hungry for lunch, I don't want to be rude or just watch them eat because that's a little weird, even for me. 

This usually happens on days when I'm in the office, which happens to be mere paces from Ayola, making it a very convenient place for the group to grab a bite. I really like coming to Ayola because the line moves fast and your food is ready in under a minute most of the time. Best of all, they serve up some of the only dolmas I like in a little side portion for under $4, that's perfect for me to nab and eat alongside my hungrier colleagues so I don't seem lunch-time creeper watching them devour their gyros and hummus platters.
author: Candice G.

description:
Used Eat24 from their Yelp business page for the first time and set a large order for pick up for myself and 4 other colleagues. Placed and paid for the order with ease from their Yelp page and by the time we took the elevator to the main floor and walked 1/2 a block over the meal was basically ready to go - so convenient.

We ordered an array of items but I was looking for something fast and simple, and given the positive reviews for the Gyros (pronounced Yee-ros) I went with the standard Beef/Lamb Gyro in the large size (9 inches) and have to say it definitely hit the spot. Nice amount of met and tzatziki sauce, good tomatoes, not too much onion and the right amount of lettuce.

All around a SUPER quick, convenient, and delicious lunch option

Eatcrest Out!
author: Kris U.

description: Finally found it again! I ate here once before and loved it. It's a lot less busy at 10:30 am compared to 1:30, but the food and service are just as great.
author: Be F.

description:
The gyro is on the salty side but overall the flavor is decent. Lines moves quickly so it's pretty good for a workday lunch. 

They seem to be experimenting with some iPad order flow but it didn't work well. It became my turn before I can complete the order on the iPad so I just abandoned it.
author: Joseph L.

description:
Love the gyro! I always order the gyro - it's quite tasty and convenient to grab a quick lunch, especially with coworkers. But -
1. The quality of the gyro varies with high deviation. One day the gyro is warm and fresh and the other day the gyro can be cold and stale. I don't know it's just me or the construction of the gyro but my gyro will always disintegrate when I am trying to eat the last one third of it.
2. I have alway heard that their fries are good. But they don't sell the fries individually. You have to buy a combo to get a drink together with the fries. I don't want the drink and therefore I have never tried their fries. : (
3. The price jumps up frequently - in fact the price rises so fast that they don't replace the menu - they put a sticker on the menu to reflect the change in the price. Haha.
But still, I would get a gyro from them from time to time. I admit it's the best in the block.
author: Frank W.

description:
They have crack fries and the wait to get your food is two minutes max.

I've been here three times this week... You can trust me on this.
author: Tina T.

description: The gyro was surprisingly good. There was something about the french fries that tasted a little off, but they were still decent. The food is priced well and the portions were satisfactory. I was kind of apprehensive to eat here because the restaurant had little seating and a faint off-putting smell, slightly reminiscent of body odor, however I was pleasantly surprised once I took the food elsewhere to eat.
author: Charles S.

description:
My go to for a filling, quick and delicious salad. I always get the Sparta Salad. It is a combination of lettuce, cucumbers, red onions, tomatoes, olives, feta cheese, grilled chicken and their delicious homemade dressing (which is their take on balsamic vinaigrette). 

It also comes with a side of warm pita (3-4 slices) for you to dip in the free hot sauce or extra salad dressing. 

Line moves quickly and the owner is super friendly.
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
For a busy lunch hour in the heart of a the hectic SOMA neighborhood you've got  to have a well-oiled machine to feed a lot of hungry people on their lunch break. And they were just that. With a smile. The line was long, but moved fast.

The Gyro Platter complete with dolmas, hummus, Greek salad, falafel, and tzatziki was delicious (especially the hummus) and was the perfect amount of food for a fast and casual lunch. I really enjoyed the variation in the platter and the flavor profile that each component brought. It's a great way to receive a sneak peek of what's on the menu for an entree. Next time, I'm getting a whole plate of dolmas and a life's supply of hummus and pita bread.
author: Frances H.

description: I got the falafel wrap with tahini sauce and everything on it. The falafel was perfectly made. It had a crunchy outside (but not too much) and a moist inside. It also was wrapped well, which made it easy to eat in the go. I would give to five stars but there was nothing special about it. If you want a really good falafel wrap that you can be confident in, go here. But if you're looking for some special, authentic Mediterranean food, I'm not sure.
author: Ahmed H.

description: Had the chicken shawarma bowl. Great flavors but the proportion of rice to chicken was off balance. Way too much rice and hardly any chicken.
author: Vivek S.

description:
OK so I was craving for something light (like fries) and my director and several coworkers recommended me this spot. I looked them up, saw the menu, looked at reviews and pictures and BAM! Forced myself to be a little hungrier so I can get a wrap also. 

Place is small but it didn't need anymore room. Waiting for the food while smelling everything...ooweee! Hunger!

Got myself a 7 inch Chicken Shawarma *spicy* with fries. Oh man. Blown away. 

The shawarma was goooood! It'll get a lil messy though but luckily I was eating it at a empty desk at work. It is HOT. Temp wise. Spicy level on point. I'm currently sweating right now (love spicy food....my body doesn't). Sauce on point. Everything on point in it. 

Fries: damn....its good! This was the item that my director told me about. Legit! Currently dipping it in the hot sauce. 

Whoever said the good stuff about the sauce: you are correct. Its good! 

All in all....I will be back!
author: A o S.

description:
Ayola is a great spot for a grab-n-go lunch. The line wasn't nearly as long as the surrounding restaurants downtown and the line moved really quickly. 

This place gives you the option to order a 7-inch-or 9-inch pita sandwich which is nice. I ordered the 7-inch lamb gyro (with added eggplant salad) and it was mouth-watering. I haven't had gyros in a long time so this definitely satisfied that craving. 

The only downside is that there are not really many places to sit inside so it's more of a carry out place
author: Ilana B.

description: So fast and satisfying. I was on my way to fast food, but I passed by Ayola and the smell drew me in. So glad I stopped for a gyro!
author: Hunter H.

description:
I work about one Saturday every three weeks on New Montgomery, and this has become my tradition for lunch.  Can't say that it's a light meal.  I usually feel like curling up in a ball afterward, but boy, it is tasty.  

Solid Gyros and fries.  The combo for $11.50 (after tax) with a soda (they have Diet Ginger Ale, rad!) is a lot of food.  Every time I come for lunch I foreswear eating that much food and returning to work.  Yet, I do it again.  Every time.  Isn't that the definition of insanity?  I suppose I should order just a Gyro, no fries (but, they are so good, and usually piping hot!), or maybe just downgrade to the 7-inch instead of the 9-inch.  

BTW - A co-worker of mine shared a taste of the lentil soup this weekend.  I may have to do that instead of the Gyros combo next time.  Mmm mmm.  

My ONE comment for improvement:  Could you get a ketchup dispenser?  I love ketchup, and it sucks to have to open 10 ketchup packets.
author: Adam S.

description: Solid place! Got a lamb-beef gyro bowl.
author: Chris D.

description:
Considering that I am always bitching about how every single place in San Francisco has no clue how to make Tzatziki sauce (no sour cream does not count, not even if you add dill) I am including how to make the damn stuff because apparently it is too hard, too complicated, and considering how much everyone is on their phones it is too difficult to look u; although I do remember "Pita Pit" getting it correct so think about that for a "ohh, no we can't have chains here in SF, that would be wrong...as starbucks/overpriced sucky burger places are everywhere. 

For a single serving
2 cups Greek yogurt (can use normal yogurt just do half sour cream)
1.5 tablespoons lemon juice (.5 to a whole lemon juiced works)
.5 garlic clove, minced
.5 large English cucumber, diced (the long, skinny ones)
salt (for salting cucumbers ie. drawing out the moisture)
1 tablespoon fresh dill or 1 tablespoon of fresh mint (or both, depending on preference)
salt & freshly ground black pepper 

you can throw the veggies in a blender, blend the fuckers, let it sit for a couple of min, then add everything else. I add pickles to mine. 

How hard is that San Francisco, is it as hard as telling the difference between lavash and pita, and how shawarma meat is not gyro.
author: Max X.

description:
I had a Gyro Platter. 
The meat was quite good. The Salad was good as well.
The sauces were not bad but less "garlicy" than I'm used to from Mediterranean restaurants in Montreal.

Overall, it was good! If I'm in SF again and have hankering for Mediterranean food, I know where to go.
author: Denis M.

description:
Perfect if you're looking for fast, affordable food.  

Pros:
- Reasonable prices. I bought a 7-inch Lamb & Beef Gyro for $7.50 (9-inch for $9.50)
- Fast service - just grab your food & go
- Meat is tender & not too salty, which is something I have experienced when eating gyros before

Cons:
- Bread is mediocre - wish it was warmer & softer
- Unfriendly cashier that seemed impatient 
- Flavor is a bit plain, but this isn't a big con, because you can always grab some of the sauces
author: Irene X.

description:
I had the pleasure of taking of class in FiDi for a week and got to try some new food. This was one of the places I went to because I was so over the basic only sandwich option around where I work. 

I got the gryo, fries, and drink combo meal. I used their kiosk to purchase because I could not tell who was standing in line and who wasn't. The place is so tiny that people are standing everywhere... especially during the lunch hour.

There are a couple bar seats to eat, but for the most part it's pretty much togo. The food came out rather quickly as after I payed at the mobile kiosk, I was wishing I had paid at the counter since it said 15 mins. However, it was very easy to use and navigate and it shows up as MobileTummy on your credit card statement. The great thing about their kiosk though is that it sends you a text when your food is ready. So if you don't feel like standing in the crowd of people in the little restaurant, then you could wait outside or go somewhere else until you get that text.

There is also this sauce that is at the counter that you can pick up when you get your food. Not knowing what it was a grabbed one and went out to a POPOS to enjoy my meal. It was a really good gyro and the fries were so fresh and crisp. So good. Would totally go back and probably often if I worked near here. I'm not sure what the sauce I grabbed was either, but it was quite delicious. Plus, thumbs up for this place having ginger ale as a beverage. Most places have just have your typical soda beverages, so kudos to Ayola too!
author: Julie L.

description:
One of my go-to lunch spots near the office.  Yes, the line can be a bit long, but that should tell you something about this place.  Regardless of how long the line is, it won't take long to get your food, since that's how fast they are.  

I love their chicken gyro's and I recommend you take some red sauce with you on the way out.  Their fries are awesome.  They crunch when you bite into them and are seasoned just right.  I've also had their beef/lamb gyro which is also really good.  Can't get much better than quick service, good food and inexpensive prices.
author: Lon H.

description: I am shocked that I haven't written a review of this place yet!  I go here at least once a week!  They have a sign out front that says they have the best fries in town and they aren't joking.  They practically melt in your mouth.  And the hot sauce that goes with it is perfect to dunk them into.  The salads are a good portion and not over priced.  The gyro meat is great on them but the chicken is tasty as well.  The place is small so it can get packed but they go really fast so you aren't waiting for more than a couple of minutes.
author: Amanda K.

description:
The lamb/beef gyro is so dank. Must be the hot sauce, so addicting!

Also has fast service during the busy lunch hour.
author: Linda D.

description:
I ate at Ayola yesterday and ordered the gyro platter. The food looked and tasted good, although I appear to have received a wonderful case of food poisoning along with it. I guess this is one case where getting something extra with your meal is not a good thing. I was immediately sick to my stomach within 5 minutes of eating, and it's gone on for almost 20 hours. 

Thanks for the food, but unfortunately, I will not be returning.
author: Ravi K.

description: I thought the food was fresh and tasty. Service was friendly. It definitely didn't taste Greek- this is more middle eastern in style and flavors but it was delicious and I would return for a quick no fuss meal. The place is small and looks kind of dirty so not so appetizing to eat in but would be great for take out
author: Piper W.

description:
Good Gyro, but the bread is pretty generic they serve it on. They have a great deal for lunch with fries. The fries are very good and nicely salted. 

The service was good, and the hot sauce was solid as well. Wouldn't really write home about it.
author: Jonah K.

description:
I tried to go healthy with the Greek salad, forgot to order a protein and my meal shaped up to be a bummer. Ugh, healthy!

BUT, I expected a loaded salad with lots of veggies. You know, the good Greek toppings. It was a bit lackluster, and I was hungry in an hour. I really do feel like I ordered wrong. 

Next time, go big or go home!
author: Rachel C.

description: good enough but not great. maybe i ordered the wrong thing, the new rice plate special with chicken and salad. lots of bros standing around too, but maybe that's just the regular old SF problem.
author: Ronny K.

description: It was great food and Kota has great customer service! Would most definitely  come back for some great food!
author: Pedro S.

description: The food was delicious. I ordered lunch for pick up and will definitely be a repeat customer.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Tip: The hot sauce is to DIE for. And the fries truly are the best in town.
author: Gitanjali R.

description: The gyros meat was quite dry. There was nothing special about the salad or the pita bread. The only thing that surprised me in a good way was that the fries were quite crispy.
author: James S.

description:
Ayola is a small little place with reasonably priced food. Because the furnishing is old and the cramp seating arrangement, I couldn't really eat my gyro comfortably. I just wanted to eat and get out. 

Also, I ordered a 7 inch gyro but noticed the cashier charged me for a 9 inch. When I told the cashier about it, she said, "Don't worry, we put in your order for the 9 inch". When my order came, I got the 7 inch. Which by the way tasted like a chicken caesar salad but with a different type of dressing.

I'll come back if I don't have any other option but this is not some place I will recommend.
author: Fanny W.

description:
Ayola is a great, quick lunch go-to in SOMA. I usually go for a chicken gyros. Their french fries ARE that good, but I try to stay away from french fries in general. 

You can also order ahead and pick-up when you're ready on Eat24 and Order Ahead.
author: Melissa S.

description:
I should probably be embarrassed by the amount of times I've been here for lunch, but I'm not! Their chicken gyro is amazing and reasonably priced, especially for the area. If you're here, you NEED to order fries with your meal! I'm not sure what they put on them, but I can't get enough. 

I find that their portions are pretty large. Whenever I finish my 7" gyro and fries, I'm always toeing that line between being really satisfied and really shocked at the amount of food my stomach can hold.
author: Rahel A.

description:
Hands-down one of the best gyros I have had ever! There are a lot of Mediterranean restaurants all within the same 0.5-1 mile radius. After performing taste tests on all of them, Ayola has had the most consistent, flavorful, and moist gyro sandwich and/or plate. 

Their fries have also been consistently good - crunchy on outside, smushy and moist on inside. 

Great job guys!!
author: Anna M.

description:
I have no real complaints with this place. They could maybe smile a bit more, but they more than make up for this.  When you think of a good fast gyros joint, Ayola should be the first place on your mind. 

I would think of this as fast food gyros joint. They get your food to you within a few minutes. This is perfect when you're looking to grab something quick for lunch, even when there is a long line.

Tip: The fries aren't that good.
author: Jaye F.

description:
This place has delicious food, and it's very affordable. If you're looking to pick up some good, quick food I highly recommend Ayola. I got the chicken gyro, and it's delicious. It's the perfect lunch. 

Unfortunately the size of the restaurant itself is tiny, and there is limited room to sit. During the lunch rush, however, the place gets so packed and people are coming in and out that you'll want to bring your lunch elsewhere. Despite it being the lunch rush when I went, I still received my food in a decent amount of time. 

I'm giving this restaurant 5 stars for its delicious food, affordability, and convenience.
author: Bianca G.

description:
A solid to-go lunch spot with fast service, it's easy to get in and out in 5-10 minutes, even in the middle of the lunch rush, when it seems to be jam-packed, but things keep moving!

The falafel is a great choice, and I like that I can get a smaller sandwich if I want. The fries are amazeballs, and are my downfall when trying to go for a healthyish lunch.
author: Jenni S.

description:
Seating for 6 people most.
Short selection of food.

Very hot and smelly.

The two of us had 2 different sandwiches and both got stomach sick! 

No point on going back
author: Max F.

description: After getting a new job, I'm a bit far from my first love, Oasis Grill. This had decent reviews and I was craving a chicken shawarma so I headed over. The wrap was decent sized but the chicken was too dry. There wasn't enough sauce and the hot sauce was not spread evenly. One side of my wrap was bland and the other half was spicy. I think I'll just trek over to Oasis Grill next time.
author: Dara S.

description: Had the chicken gyro and it was pretty delicious. The chicken was very juicy and flavourful unlike other Greek fast food places I've been to where the meat is often overcooked and dry. Definitely recommend this place for a quick bite. Note that there is very minimal sitting, so this place is really only for takeout.
author: Michael M.

description:
Okay, okay: with 17 check-ins and counting, the time to write an update has come.

Once I gave Ayola's chicken the cold shoulder and moved on to the gyro platter (lamb served with salad, pita, and hummus), I became a fan. The gyro meat is tender and well-seasoned and you get a good amount of salad -  now I order the platter instead of the Troy salad because the addition of hummus and pita make it much more interesting. 

I love that these guys run smoother than most well-oiled machines - I never fear their line, knowing that I'll be in and out in 5 minutes flat... or less.

Don't forget the hot sauce!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
I work a few blocks away from this place and order lunch from here probably 3 times a week. It's SO bomb. I usually order the 3-item sampler and have tried just about every side on the menu. The dolmas, spanakopita and French fries are my favorite, but the baba ganoush and tabouleh are awesome too. They also have great shawarma if you're looking for something more filling.

When I went in today, they had run out of spanakopita so they gave me free baklava. They're always so nice when I pick up my order and the food is ready in no time. If you find yourself in FiDi and in need of a good lunch to go, I highly recommend Ayola.
author: Erin W.

description:
There's nothing fancy about Ayola, but I've been excited to haver another Troy salad (aka: gyro salad) since first indulging about a month ago. I returned to SF (my home away from home) this week and when fellow yelper, Jelena Z*, asked what I wanted for lunch I requested Ayola.  

Based on Jelena's recommendation I went with the gyro platter, which may even be better (imagine that) than the salad because they give you pita and hummus in addition to a smaller, but large enough salad topped with gyro meat. It was just as tasty as I remembered. Since there are just a few tables in this tiny restaurant we took our order to go, as most customers seem to do here.

The next day I was lucky enough to lunch with Jelena again. She asked what I was in the mood for and I suggested my favorite platter again. Fortunately, she's a fan too and was happy to oblige.  And once again... so tasty.

I'll be back "home" to SF in a few weeks and I have a feeling I'll be making my way back to Ayola once again!


* http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=MGPQVLsODMm9ZtYQW-g_OA
author: Andrea R.

description:
I ordered the 7" inch Chicken Schwama, and it was ready in just a few minutes. I loved every bite. The chicken was warm, well-seasoned and sans-fat. The additional toppings and sauce were perfect, but I take issue with the bread. Yummy though it was, it was super messy. A slightly larger, thinner lavash would give you more room to wrap it properly and thus prevent some of the spillage. 

Overall, a quick, tasty, affordable lunch within steps of the office - I'll take it!
author: Julie S.

description:
The fries at this place are *ridiculously* good.  I often tell others that I would make a second trip to this place to get an order of their fries to go along with a sandwich or burger that I purchased somewhere else -- they are really that good (and, don't forget the sauce).  They always think I'm joking, but I'm really not.

Weird as it seems, I really like the "Hortopita".  I am not a vegetarian: this is just a really tasty roasted eggplant and salad-ish mix rolled into a pita that I really like, especially when coupled with their most excellent fries.
author: Alex Y.

description:
In a nutshell:
+ "Fries please" are the words you're looking for.
+ Quick lunch.
+ Their spicy tomato sauce? (dipping?) is da bomb. Take two! and you'll not regret.
~ Service with a smile? What do you mean?

Quick lunch spot in SoMa that doesn't break the bank. Being a vegetarian, I usually for the Falafel wrap. The lunch line can get somewhat long but they work through it pretty fast and once I order, I get my food within 5 mins tops. The falafels are good enough and the wrap itself goes well with the spicy tomato sauce. It's a take-out place and I have never seen anyone eat there in-store.

Sometimes, they do mess up the order. I got Lamb (instead of Falafel) couple of times and realized it only after being back in the office. One time, I went back and got it exchanged. The other, I just let it go as I didn't have the time/wasn't in the mood to deal with it.

Their fries are really good, something that folks rush for when we get them for happy hours. But, count them while you eat or you'll feel sorry afterwards :D I'll be back for a quick lunch.
author: Venkatesan P.

description: Dropped by in the afternoon and got a beef Gyro, sat down and enjoyed the best one I have had in forever, it is big and I usually never finish one but I had to because it was that good.  The price is right and the only thing I would change next time is that I would ask for extra tzatziki sauce because it was so perfect.
author: Valerie G.

description: I work right next to Ayola and it's delicious aroma lingers in the area as i walk past it everyday on my way to work. I've eaten here a few times and I've never had a bad order or ever felt unsatisfied. I've eaten at a few gyro places in the bay area, i love the gyro! Ayola is a pretty solid choice for the traditional gyro I'm used to eating, (gyro + fries). Recently I had a lunch order that didn't quite work out from elsewhere and I went searching nearby work for something to calm my grumbling tummy. I decided on a 7" gyro with fries... and Falafel! I thought I had good falafel in the past but I never knew what really good falafel was until I took a bite out of Ayola's Falafel! Perfectly moist, not dry, perfectly seasoned, and crunchy on the outside... It was the best I've had! Their gyros were great as usual, and they don't skimp on any ingredients which I love. They have amazing fries, better than most gyro places I've been to along with their red sauce... this place can't be beat! They are always consistently great.
author: Rehana K.

description: This is a solid spot in my weekly lunch rotation. I get the Sparta Salad or Gyro platter when i'm craving hummus -- and always ask for no dairy, which has never been a problem. Food is great and the staff is both speedy and sweet!
author: DeAnna C.

description:
One good thing about working in the FiDi during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day - in fact, the only good thing about working that week - is being able to go to some of the nearby spots that otherwise have long queues during the regular lunch hour. That finally gave me an excuse to try Ayola next to the Pac Bell building on New Montgomery. It's such a tiny place that I didn't think it could possibly be worth the wait. But this week, I simply walked in, ordered and even sat down at the one and only table to eat it because no one else came in. I had the 9-inch Lamb & Beef Gyros Sandwich for $7.35 (see photo).

While I'm not preoccupied with size except when I'm looking in the rear view mirror where objects appear larger than they appear, I figured the dollar premium was worth the extra two inches. It was quite tasty with the pita quite thick and soft, the tzatziki sauce refreshing, and the meat flavorful enough even if I couldn't tell the beef from the lamb. For another $2.50, you can get a can of soda and a bag of fries. I'm not sure why they give you so many fries, piping hot and very thick, but if you need your starch, by all means, go for it. Now I know Sunrise Deli and now Gyro King are nearby, but I think Ayola is a worthy cure for my Zorba-like, plate-smashing urges.

FOOD - 4 stars...a fine gyros, nothing fancy in the fixings
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...it's a closet, isn't it?
SERVICE - 3 stars...transactional but with a smile
TOTAL - 4 stars...ooompah!
author: Ed U.

description:
Ayola is a dependable lunch spot and I enjoy coming here. Even if the line is long, you don't wait longer than 8 minutes to get your food. The service is quick and you pretty much get what you order. 
I usually go for the 9 inch chicken gyro ($7.50) and the red hot sauce is a must. They even have them in to-go containers for you by the cash register. The fries are also a treat if I'm planning on going to the gym that night- they are delicious.
author: Grace L.

description: Ayola is hands down the best to-go restaurant in SOMA. I highly recommend the Troy or Neptune salads, don't forget to grab a side of their free harissa hot sauce!
author: Jacqueline R.

description:
Ayola is one of our go-to dinner joints at the office for their consistently great food, fast service and convenient location.

I made the mistake of not ordering fries for whatever bullshit diet I was on but have learned my lesson since trying them for the first time. They look like regular ol' fries but they are perfectly crispy without being crunchy, seasoned like a boss, and hardy. Any lover of this starchy staple can appreciate Ayola's execution.

Their Sparta salad makes me want to shout in the deepest, growliest voice from the depths of my soul and is equally delicious. Get it. Eat it. Love it. Then deal with the food coma like a champ.

Holla at Ayola.
author: Kat C.

description: I had just recently had greek a few times back home so when we ended up at Ayola for lunch, I decided to try something different (for me that is). I typically don't consider salad a meal but the Troy Salad was more food than the gyros. The shawarma meat was excellent and seasoned just right. There was plenty of it which made it a filling meal too. A great grab and go option that had our lunch for 6 ready in a matter of minutes. I will definitely be back on my next trip.
author: Scotty C.

description: What happened to this place?? I've worked in the area for the past several years and this place has always been in heavy rotation for lunch options. The food IS good, the fries are insane. Having not been there for awhile, I made my way over recently was was met with a pretty crappy experience. First, the kitchen floor behind the counter was completely filthy with shrapnels of meat and veg scattered all over the place. Secondly, the guy behind the counter kept walking back and forth to and from the fry station nibbling on fries in between taking orders. Dude, I get it, I love those fries too, but how about you eat it on your own goddamn time? You're handling dirty bills and coins and now your dirty mitts are all over the damn fries. Gross.
author: Joe C.

description: There are few things I have consistent cravings for, but the chicken gyro with hummus instead of tzatziki is definitely high on the list. The key to its success is how they prep the chicken. The chicken is cooked on the rotating spit just like the lamb/beef is. It's super succulent and oh so good! Get the fries too, you won't be disappointed.
author: Marissa B.

description:
The gyro was pretty good but the chicken gyro was pretty bad. 
The eggplant salad was not bad but the hummus was not good. 
Taboule salad was great!
The tzatziki was above average. 
The falafel was dry and bland. 
The dolmas tasted like they were from a tin can. 
Pittas were decent, all things considered. 
All in all, meh...
author: Assaf G.

description:
Decent gyros. I haven't tried many places with Greek / Mediterranean food in SF so hard to compare with alternatives. 

The chicken showarma was very dry.
author: Nuno S.

description:
It's been WAY too long since I treated myself to a gyro. Fortunately, there's a cool, hole-in-the-wall joint near my office called Ayola. Every time I've walked past it during lunch hour, there's been a line out the door.

Today, I finally timed it perfectly (I stopped in around 1:45pm). I ordered up a chicken gyro at the counter, and 5 minutes later, I totally Greeked out. For just $8 you get a warm lavash flatbread full of moist chicken, lettuce, onion, tomato, and yogurt. In a word - delicious! Totally hit the spot. I could barely finish my meal (but rest assured, I did). ** I highly recommend getting a free order of the spicy, red sauce (which is situated on the counter). Personally, I like me a gyro with a little heat.

I'd like to go back soon and try their Greek salads and their hummus. My co-worker swears by their fries, so maybe I'll order that next time as well (food coma, be damned).

The only thing that isn't great about the place is the size. Unfortunately, when it comes to take-out lunch places, size does matter. After you order your meal, you sort of stand around and feel kind of silly. There's no place to sit or wait for your food. When other people come in, they automatically think that you're waiting in line (when all you're doing is just waiting for food).

But alas, this a small gripe. Ayola - you and I will meet again soon!
author: Kevin B.

description:
lamb gyro short and a baklava togo, no place to sit I suggest you take it togo, this place is small literally hole in the wall small when walking in you can see to the back where everything is prepped fairly clean considering all the foot traffic walking in and out of this place. 

the lamb gyro short was good hella lettuce, hella lamb on that pita type roll, there was a tad to much of that white sauce drowning the flavors on everybite. my description would be like a cesear salad with no salad just the anchovie diced with olive oil and white sauce with no lettuce, not saying the gyro tasted like this just saying ease up on the sauce a lil, for the bits of lettuce not buried in sauce it was good fresh not stale, the lamb also equally good heavy not gamey  made just right not dry it was tender and juicy, even the wrap was well proportioned to hold all the sauce, lettuce and lamb definitely something to try if in the city for a quick bite maybe ask for lite sauce

baklava - cant go wrong here, flaky, dense, not oily, bottom crumbing out when eating shows that it hasnt been sitting in fridge all night nor oil collected to hold it together

for something quick hell yeah imma come back

food *** gyro minus all that sauce would of been solid **** sadly overpowering sauce only a *** lamb good, lettuce fresh, pita fresh. baklava can't deny the sweets get 1 or 2 hahaaha
price $ for a short gyro 6.25 & baklava vame out to be under $10
service **** quick, efficient
ambiance ** no place to sit take it togo if you do find a seat it wont be comfortable
author: Clarence A.

description:
Gyro and fries? Don't mind if I do...

Sometimes a girl needs to go beyond a simple salad for lunch, especially if she's tired and skipped breakfast. Sure, kale might be a better choice, but it just doesn't taste the same.

Walk up to the storefront in FiDi, order, get a number and wait maybe 5 minutes for your food to come out hot and fresh. There's even a gyro special - sandwich, fries and a large drink for $9.95 + tax. In that part of town, $10 lunch is hard to come by, hence the long line out the door during weekdays.

A greasy bag full o' food gets me excited! Not to mention the red hot sauce for dipping your fries. If there's an opportunity to take a little snooze after your noontime meal, go for it.
author: Abby S.

description:
One of my favorite spots for lunch in the FiDi. 

**Do not be disheartened by the line out the door.  Service here is quick, and the line moves quickly.

My favorite are the "plain" gyro (labelled simply as "gyro" on the menu, but I refer to it as the lamb option) and the chicken gyro.  The lamb gyro is not gamy at all and robust in flavor. So so so so good.

Do not forget to pick up one of those red sauces at the counter after you pay.  They are free and make the gyro and fries that much better.

Note: They have a "special" posted on the door, but it's nothing different from what's on the menu.
author: Patricia K.

description:
I love Mediterranean and Middle Eastern flavors, especially shwarma, and after checking out the menu and the line spilling out the door on a Thursday afternoon, I was seriously excited to get my hands on theirs. I know shwarma to be heavily seasoned spit rotisseried meat (typically lamb or beef) shaved and griddled briefly before going into a pita. Ayola's menu describes it as roasted chicken with sumac and tzaziki, not traditional but sounds good, And what ended up in the sandwich was baked/poached chicken, with a light dusting of seasoning and a bland yogurt sauce. The saving grace was the home made spicy sauce you take with you. It was the only thing with flavor. Along side of the sandwich I ordered fries and dolmades (grape leaves). The fries were under done, and the dolmades were garden variety and served with the same bland tzaziki. 

After this meal, it was clear the line out the door was because of the fast and friendly service. Ayola caters to the quick lunch crowd coming from the many offices that surround it, not the food conscious consumer. So the lesson here, strong branding and great service don't always land you a five start review in my world. Everything has to measure up.
author: Michael T.

description:
Good gyros here. get the lamb!

fries are great too

super fast service. watch out for the lunch crowd though.  it can get really busy at rush hour
author: Jimming C.

description:
I love to get down on some Greek food.

Despite the lunch rush and a long line, this was such a quick option. My group was in and out in less than ten minutes. Bonus: it was next to where our work sessions were taking place.

I went in for a salad, but apparently blacked out when I got to the register and ordered chicken shawarma. It was worth the extra calories... although I'm not sure that shawarma is the right term for this sandwich. It's more like a chicken gyro IMO. Whatever you want to call it, make sure you grab a side of the special hot sauce to go with it.

Speaking of sides, the falafel was just okay. The dolma... yum. Grape leaves perfectly rolled and packed with rice deliciousness. They're not as good as my sister's, but that's tough competition. She makes the best. Don't tell her I said that.

This is definitely a place you want to hit up for a to-go style lunch. Ayola is pretty tight quarters. Not a whole lot of room to sit down and eat.

The staff cranks out food like a well-oiled machine. Solid lunch option if you work in this area.
author: Nikki W.

description: I grab lunch here every time I travel to San Francisco. The Spartan salad is great and I can never quite eat it all. Free pita bread is also a great bonus.
author: John P.

description:
This place has quickly become one of my defaults. Not only is it close to work, but regardless of the line, you're never inside this place for more than a minute or so. You tell them what you want. You sign the receipt. Two seconds later the food's in your hands. Too easy.

As far as the food itself, I've only had the falafel wrap and fries, but both are pretty good. Maybe a little pricey, but even though the wrap seems small, it fills you up. And if you're really ambitious, you can try the 9 inch wrap (as opposed to 7 inch), and that for certain you will not finish.

All in all, this place is a pretty solid catch. I'm a big falafel guy, so you know this place is one of my top snacky spots. I'll probably go there a couple times next week.
author: Sahil P.

description:
Ayola is definitely one of my regular lunch spots mostly because I can get a delicious lunch without having to chomp through slices of bread or a giant bowl of rice. My go-to order is the Gyros Platter, which has a salad, hummus, pita bread, and a very generous serving of gyro meat. The meat is not overly salty although I do with it could be a little warmer than room-temp when it's served. The pita, however, is warm and chewy and goes great with that hummus on the side or on its own. 

The lunch line goes by pretty fast so this is definitely one of my quicker options.
author: Virginia T.

description:
This place is alright - not bad but not great. Came here during the weekend for lunch and ordered the beef and lamb gryro - there is a 7in or 9in option. The woman who took my order was really nice, but the place itself is pretty small with only one table and some counter seats. 

The gyro was fine, but nothing special. I personally thought the meat could have been a little more moist and flavorful. Overall, I would say this place would be a good option if you work in the area and just want a quick bite to eat during your lunch hour.
author: Robia L.

description:
Came in here again after many years. They still make the best french fries in the city, as far as I can tell.
